Dialogue.Line: Perhaps we've landed on top of something.
Yes.
Or inside something.
Hmm? This says everything has stopped, but the ship.
What did you mean, Barbara, inside something?
Perhaps that's why we still appear to be moving.
Try the scanner, Doctor.
Covered with static. Let's try it again, Susan.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The screen is just streaks of static

Dialogue.Line: That could be caused by an unsuppressed motor.
Yes, or a magnetic field.
Shall we go outside, Grandfather?
No, I shan't be happy until I've solved this little mystery.
I don't know why we ever bother to leave the ship.
You're still thinking about the experiences you had with the Aztecs.
No, I've got over that now.
There's one thing about it, Doctor. We're certainly different from when we started out with you.
That's funny. Grandfather and I were talking about that just before you came in. How you've both changed.
Well we've all changed.
Have I?
Yes.
Yes, it all started out as a mild curiosity in a junkyard, and now it's turned out to be quite a, quite a great spirit of adventure, don't you think?
Yes. We've had some pretty rough times and even that doesn't stop us. It's a wonderful thing, this ship of yours, Doctor. Taken us back to prehistoric times, the Daleks.
Marco Polo, Marinus.
And the Aztecs.
Yes, and that extraordinary quarrel I had with that English king, Henry the Eighth. You know, he threw a parson's nose at me.
What did you do?
Threw it back, of course. Take them to the Tower, he said. That's why I did it.
Why?
The Tardis was inside the Tower.
Of course, it was long before you appeared on the scene. However, now, let us get back to this little problem. Open the door, Susan.
Have you checked everything, Doctor?
Yes, yes. Plenty of fresh air, temperature normal.
Oh, just the unknown, then.
Precisely.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They walk out into a room with people in uniform sitting in chairs, very still

Dialogue.Line: You were right, Barbara. We have landed in something.
It's a spaceship. Close the door, Susan. Let us be careful. There's been some kind of catastrophe here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian takes the pulse of one man. He's intact, flexible, but

Dialogue.Line: Dead.
This one's a girl.
I'm afraid she's the same. What could have happened? I can't see a wound or anything.
Suffocation, Doctor?
I never make uninformed guesses, my friend, but certainly that's one answer. Oh, dear, dear, dear, what a tragedy you know. She's only a few years older than Susan.
Grandfather, let's go back to the Tardis.
Why?
I don't know. I've got a feeling about this.
Yes, I can sense something too.
You mean that whatever it was killed them could kill us?

Chesterton, have you noticed anything about this watch? (and the man's) Neither of them are working. These are the non-winding type. A movement of the wrist recharges the spring inside for twenty four hours.
Yes, and they both stopped at about three o'clock.
Yes, then suppose we say that they've only just stopped. Now that would mean that the last movement of their wrists would be at least twenty four hours ago.
Grandfather, he's still warm.
Then they've only just died.
It doesn't make sense, does it. But the facts are all here. I think it would be wise if we returned to the ship and left these people. There's nothing we can do for them.
No, we can't even bury them.
Come along, open the door, Susan.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The man groans and slumps forward over his desk

Dialogue.Line: His heart had stopped beating, Doctor. He was dead.
(something)
What do you want? Yes?
Over there.
Where? There?
Behind you.
Here?
No, on the left.
What, this? (a metal box)
Yes, that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian gives it to him, and a heartbeat starts up

Dialogue.Line: Carol. Place this against Carol's chest.
I'm sorry, Carol's dead.
Please, do as I ask.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The heartbeat sound and she wakes up

Dialogue.Line: You were both dead.
Grandfather, what was in that box?
It's a heart resuscitator. When you found us, we were in a very long sleep, but we weren't dead. My name is Maitland. This is Carol Richmond, my co-astronaut.
Tell me, are you from the Earth?
Yes.
So are we. How's it looking?
The Earth, do you mean?
Yes.
Still too much air traffic.
They got it off the roads, did they?
You might say that, yes.
Barbara and I, we come from London. Tell me, is Big Ben still on time?
What century do you come from? The twenty first, perhaps?
No, the twentieth.
I see.
What's Big Ben?
Well, it's a clock. Near Westminster Abbey.
Yes, you see, the whole lower half of England is called Central City now. There hasn't been a London for four hundred years. We come from the twenty 8th century.
Captain Maitland, these people must leave immediately.
Yes, you will have to.
But there are so many things we want to know.
There's only danger here for you. You must go.
Danger? What sort of danger?
It's better that you don't know what happened to us.
But we might be able to help you.

No. No, Barbara. I learned not to meddle in other people's affairs years ago. (Ian laughs) Now, now, now, don't be absurd. There's not an ounce of curiosity in me, my dear boy. Tell me, why are you in danger?
Very well, I'll try to explain. Out there is a planet we call the Sense Sphere. The creatures on it, the Sensorites, have always prevented us from leaving this area of space.
You mean they have some kind of power over your craft.
Exactly. But it's not that simple. They not only control our craft, they have some influence over us as well.
Hypnosis, do you mean?
No, I do not mean hypnosis.
Well, what then?
Somehow they have some control over our brains. They are hostile, these Sensorites, but in the strangest possible way. They won't let us leave this area of space yet they don't attempt to kill us.
What had happened when we found you?
The same thing that's happened many times before. The Sensorites have put us into a deep sleep that gives the appearance of death, and yet they've never made any actual effort to destroy us.
Far from it. We both have very hazy recollections of them returning from time to time to our ship to actually feed us.
Doesn't add up at all.
This is why you must leave us at once.
Yes. The Sensorites may try to prevent you from leaving.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An alien hand holds a device over the Tardis lock

Dialogue.Line: I can smell something burning.
So can I.
You mustn't delay any longer.
I'm inclined to agree with him, Doctor. But surely there's something we can do for you?
No. Nobody can help us.
Grandfather, couldn't we take them back with us?
We cannot leave this ship.
You see, there's John to think of too.
John?
Ian, there is something burning.
Yes, I think you're right. Maitland, you wouldn't have anything shorting, would you?
No, that's not possible.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Amid smoke, the alien hand withdraws the Tardis lock mechanism from the door

Dialogue.Line: It seems to be coming from over here.
You have additional crew, I take it?
Yes.
Doctor, you must go. Leave us.
Well, it seems to me that there's nothing else I can do. Goodbye, my friend. Bye, bye, my child. Come along, Susan.
Goodbye.
It's stronger over here, Doctor.
Oh? Perhaps it's coming from inside the Tardis.
Grandfather!
Good gracious! They've taken the lock!
It's not so much the lock, it's the opening mechanism. The door's permanently locked!
Permanently? But there must be some way of getting in? What can we do, Doctor? Break down the door?
And disturb the field dimensions inside the Tardis? We dare not. We've been most effectively shut out.
The Sensorites?
Who else?
What do they want with us?
I don't know. And why have they kept those other two in captivity, hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: the ship shakes

Dialogue.Line: The Sensorites! Get back! Get away!
Must get up the other end.
What is happening, my friend? Can't you control the ship?
I'm powerless. The Sensorites are stronger than I am.
Which is your parallel thrust?
There.
Right. Velocity, Chesterton. Check velocity.
It's not even on the unit marker, Doctor.
Don't try and control the spacecraft. It's suicide, I tell you.
Please go away.
The velocity needle's hitting the red, Doctor.
Right, stabilisers, Maitland.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The ship stops shaking

Dialogue.Line: Oh, at last. At last. The ship was rolling about on its axis.
Grandfather, look! We're heading straight for it.
It's the Sense Sphere.
Where's your deflection rays? Maitland! Deflection rays.
There, the white panel. But it's useless.
Well, we'll see about that. We'll see about that. Reading, please.
Mach three, braking one.
Nineteen miles to the nearest point of impact.
Closing fast.
Barbara, we're going to hit. We're going to hit!
Lifting slightly.
You're on collision course.
Jet. Jet course. Port. Now.
Velocity still rising.
Jet reverse. Starboard. Now.
Increasing to mach four. Heading straight for point of impact.
The altitude is still falling.
Mach four.
Barbara, see that panel? Check status. Three lights normal.
Yes. Three lights on.
Boost engines. Forward thrust and lock.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The planet fills the viewscreen, then they veer off to the left

Dialogue.Line: Why couldn't I do it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: later

Dialogue.Line: Well, my friend, are you feeling better?
Yes, my head's much clearer.
Yes, well, I rather fancy that's settled that little bit of solution. You know, I think these Sensorites have found a way to take control of your minds.
Do you think they were deliberately trying to kill us, Doctor?
No, no, I don't. I think it was an exercise in fear and power.
Yes, but for some reason or other your minds aren't open to them.
Yes, and you found a way to resist them, whereas Maitland here, his power to resist was taken from him.
I was afraid.
You weren't afraid. They just made you hopeless.

Yes, they're dangerous and cunning, these people. But that's not all. Things are very strange here. You know, they can control, they can frighten and yet they don't attempt to kill you. Furthermore, they feed you and keep you alive. All this is most extraordinary.
Yes. Talking about food, I shall be glad when we eat. How's it coming along?
All right. Be ready in a minute.
Iron rations a la carte.
Well, from the size of our stocks, they've obviously been giving us their own food.
What about water, Carol?
Down there on the right.
Right, we'll find it.
Tell me, have either of you ever met any of these creatures or seen them?
John has.
Ah, he's the other member of your crew, isn't he.
Yes, our mineralogist.
I'd like to have a talk with him.
I'm afraid that's out of the question.
Oh? Why not?
I'd rather not talk about it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara and Susan walk past the tank marked water to a hatch

Dialogue.Line: I suppose she meant the water was through this door. Let's try it.
I can't see any handle on the door. Try this. That doesn't work.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: then she spots the electric eye and waves her hand in front of it. The hatch opens

Dialogue.Line: That's funny. Oh, I see, it's the ray. I must have broken the connection.
Let's get that water. I'm dying of thirst.
Yes, so am I.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They step through the hatch

Dialogue.Line: Well, down here on the right, she said.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And another hand shuts the hatch behind them. It belongs to a shuffling man with a glazed expression
The women find a small room

Dialogue.Line: I don't think we should stay in here.
(picking up a book) Hey, this is bliss.
I wonder where that water is?
I don't know.
Shh. Listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The shuffling footsteps come closer

Dialogue.Line: Don't you see? John may be able to give us some valuable information.
I told you. You can't see him.
You're both being rather secretive.
Where are the others?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maitland rushes to the hatch and tries to open it

Dialogue.Line: We should have warned them.
What is it? What's wrong?
The door's been locked on the other side. Quickly. They're in danger. We must get in from the other end.
This way. This is the other way through.
Oh, it's no use. The ray's been jammed on the other side.
I'm sorry, Ian. There's nothing we can do.
But what is it? What's wrong? What's going on inside there?
It's no use, no use.
Barbara! Susan!
No! No, please. No!
Are there Sensorites in there?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The shuffling man comes right up to Barbara and Susan, they step to one side and he falls over. They run back down the corridor but the hatch doesn't open for them. They duck into a store room instead
The man comes in as they hide behind the filing cabinet, and starts crying, then staggers out again without seeing them

Dialogue.Line: We must find out about John.
We've been over this a hundred times before, Carol.
But the other times were different. The Sensorites made our decisions for us.
As far as we know they still do.
But the Doctor and the others showed us we can resist them. We can! It's only fear that makes us weak, that's all.
That may be so, but we mustn't go in there, Carol. It's too dangerous.
What you really mean is, I mustn't go in there. You're afraid for me, aren't you?
I know what John means to you.
The last time I saw him, he didn't even know my name. I must see him. I must find out. Besides, there are the girls.
All right.
Maitland, you must get that door opened.
Yes, I'll have to cut round the lock.
All right, well get on with it.
I'll get the machine rigged up.
Carol, tell me. What is it that you're both afraid of?

John's in there with your friends. He and I were going to get married when we got back to the Earth. The Sensorites attacked him far more than Captain Maitland and me. I had to sit there helplessly and watch him get worse and worse.
You mean they've taken over his mind.
Yes.
What's it done to him? Carol, you've got to tell me.
He'll be frightened of strangers. He may become violent.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara and Susan sneak out of the storage room, but don't see John leaning against the wall. He pushes a lever then shuffles after them. They cannot open any other doors. Just as they think he's going to attack them, he falls to his knees

Dialogue.Line: He's crying.
Who are you? You look like my sister. Have you come to help me? Four years.
Are you one of the crew of the spaceship? You want to tell me something? About yourself?
Is he trying to say he's ill?
Yes. Ill.
(comforting him) Don't be afraid. We'll take care of you.
What do you think happened to him, Barbara?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maitland is cutting into the door with a sonic device

Dialogue.Line: Where's the power come from?
Electro-magnectics. We should be to the locks very soon.
You say you haven't seen John for months?
He was dangerous once the Sensorites got at his brain.
Can't you go faster? Susan's in there.
It won't be long now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a noise, Maitland stops

Dialogue.Line: Now what is it? Get on with the job, please.
Listen, don't you hear it? I thought there was something else.
You mean that high-pitched whine? Is that it?
Sensorites.
They must be near. That noise is caused by the machines that carry them through space.
Carol, get back to your instruments. Doctor, would you take the controller seat?
Anything but this awful waiting.
What about Barbara and Susan.
There's no time now. Look for glowing lights on the move about the ship.
How will they attack us?
They won't. Not in the normal way.
Then how can we defend ourselves.
You'll find out soon enough. Look out there. There they are! See them moving?
Yes, but they look miles away.
It won't take them long to get here.
How long do you think it'll take them, Doctor?
I don't know. They must have made the journey before. They were here before, remember? They took away the lock mechanism from my ship.
Yes. Probably took it back to their own planet.
Yes, and now they're coming back, with what orders? To take over our minds? Hmm? Or to kill us?
Do you hear that?
It's coming from outside.
No, you need rest. There's nothing wrong.
I'll protect you.
Yes. All right. You'll protect us.
Steady, Chesterton. The calmer you are, the stronger.
Doctor, look at these two.
Maitland. Maitland! Can you hear me? Fear, my boy. It's loosened his mind. It gives the Sensorites a chance to control it.
Doctor, that thing's still out there.
Oh, ignore it. Maitland!
Yes. I hear you.
There's work to be done, my boy. Work. Understand?
Work.
He's responding.
Yes, a door to be opened.
A door? Yes.
Danger on the other side.
John. Yes, we must get the two girls out.
Good, good, good.
All we want you to do is open the door.
No. I'll protect you.
But our friends are out there.
They're dead. All dead.
But we were just with them.
Just a few minutes ago. What is it?
They're here. Inside here.
John, open the door.
Frighten them? No, I can't do that. No. No.
Somebody's talking to him. Inside his mind.
No, don't force me. You can't. I won't do it. My head! Pain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: unintelligible

Dialogue.Line: Somebody's ordering him to do something, I know they are. Something to harm us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: At the hatchway

Dialogue.Line: I'll have to use the cutter.
Oh, not again. How long will this take?
It's the only way.
Yes, I know. Just that I'm so worried about Barbara and Susan.

Now, now, now. Try and contain your emotions. Use self-control. Otherwise it confuses the brain and leaves it wide open to an attack by the Sensorites. Look at Maitland here. Fear and inertia left him vulnerable.
Yes, it's true enough, Doctor.
The Sensorites are in the ship now.
What? How did they get here?
Through the loading bay.
But that can't be where Barbara and Susan are now?
No, but we must get to them as soon as possible.
Nobody's arguing about that.
But that man John's with them.
The Sensorites have control over John's mind. They may force him to obey their orders.
How's it coming.
Slowly, but it's working.
If only we knew what was happening on the other side of this door. Barbara! Susan!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They can hear Ian thumping on the hatch

Dialogue.Line: Listen. It's coming from outside.
Yes, I can just hear it. It must be Ian trying to get through.
Yes.
Give me your hand. They want me to frighten you. I mustn't give way.
He's so tense, Barbara. Can't we help him?
John, we're not afraid.
You're not afraid?
Not while we have you to protect us.
It's quiet and peaceful here. There's no real danger.
The Sensorites.
We're your friends, John.
Friends. No, they are my friends!
Barbara, I've got an idea.
What?
He's quiet now, but we can't be sure the Sensorites won't make him help them. Look, if they can use their brains, why can't we use ours?
To defend him?

Yes, and ourselves. Grandfather and I landed on a planet once called Esto. The plants there used thought transference. If you stood in between two of the plants, they set up a sort of screeching noise. Grandfather said it was because they were aware of another mind.
Breaking in on their communications.
Yes, exactly. I thought if we both tried together.
Well anything's better than just sitting here.
Sensorites! They're near us now.
You see? If we both think of the same thing at the same time.
What do you mean? We defy you. Something like that?
Yes. Yes, we defy you. We've got to picture the words very clearly in our minds. We must both concentrate very hard. Ready?
Yes. When I count to five. One, (cut to Sensorites) four, five.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Sensorites clutch their big heads in pain, then Susan faints
Maitland starts to lift the hatch

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's jammed. I'll have to cut the whole section out.
We can't wait. I'll give you a hand. Ready?
That's it.
It's going.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And they push the hatch door up and open, and go in
Later -

Dialogue.Line: Yes, it might be possible for Susan's thoughts to reach out to the Sensorites.
So we really can resist them?
Yes. And there's that friend of yours, you know. John. We must look after him. Let me see now. Of course, they have a hold of his mind, you know.
He's sleeping peacefully now.
Yes, I wonder. Did Susan release the pressure?
I had hundreds of voices in my mind, Grandfather.
Yes, and that was a dangerous thing to do, child. Because you were strong-willed and without fear, they didn't harm you.
He's resting now. Did you know his hair was almost white?
There's nothing wrong with that.
In a man of thirty, Doctor? And he looks so old. Why have the Sensorites done this? What do they want from us?
I

Doctor. John muttered something just now, before he passed out. Sounded like, the dreams of avarice. Now, on Earth we have a saying. Rich beyond the dreams of avarice. I think he's discovered something. Would explain why he's had the worst of it from the Sensorites.
Yes. What were John's duties?
He's our mineralogist.

You see? Makes sense. John mumbling something about riches. I think he must have discovered something that the Sensorites wanted to keep secret, so they silenced him and kept all of you prisoners about their planet.
I see. And now they're trying to do the same to us. We must get the lock of the Tardis back. Have you tried talking to them?
Talking to them?
Yes, we must try. We must.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Sensorites look the same, with beards that grow upwards to hide their mouths

Dialogue.Line: (soft-spoken, holding a microphone to his forehead) The first elder is communicating. Be alert while I listen. Yes. The first elder is interested in human voice that said we defy you.
(a deeper voice) The human creatures who are newly arrived seem to possess more intelligence than the others.
The first elder said that they have less fear of us. We are to stay here and watch, and listen to them closely. If they try to attack us with force, we are to summon our warriors to destroy them.
One spectroscope, Doctor.
So I see.
I do remember he was beginning to take a reading of the minerals in the vicinity.
And then what happened?
That was the first time the Sensorites attacked us.
Would you like to look at that graph for a moment?
Yes. Oh, there's nothing much here. Very ordinary collection of things. Oxygen, hydrogen, sodium.
What's that?
It's a spectrograph, Susan. You see these lines? They represent the emission wavelengths.
Oh, yes, of course.
No, there certainly isn't anything very special indicated on this.
You're very strange people.
Are we?
Well, you've come from nowhere and you seem to be going nowhere.
We're very dependant on the Doctor. He leads and we follow.
Travel without a purpose?
Oh, no, there's a purpose in it. He's trying to get us back to our own time. On Earth.
Oh, I see.
Isn't' it a better thing to travel hopefully than arrive?
Anything's better than circling round a planet for ever and being kept alive. Alive. It's been more like a living death.
(having looked through a notebook) I just don't understand. There must be a clue here somewhere. There must be.
Well I don't know, Doctor. Certainly isn't here.

I studied it whenever I could, but it didn't look like anything that would cause much excitement. The Sense Sphere is just an ordinary planet with a slightly bigger land mass than usual, but that's all.
Yes. That's very interesting. May I?
Certainly.
Excuse me.
I know the Sensorites have discovered thought transference.
Yes. And when John discovered something, he became so excited that his mind opened up and broadcast it to the Sensorites. And it was something they wanted kept a secret.
What? What is this? What was it Chesterton said? Rich beyond the dreams of avarice. Yes. Of course. Of course! I know what he found.
What?
Molybdenum. It's here, in the graph, but it's all mixed up with the lines so it doesn't make obvious reading.
Molybdenum?
Yes.
It resists very high temperatures.

Yes. It's used as an alloy in steel. In fact this machine would be useless without it. Now let me see. Iron melts at one thousand five hundred and thirty nine degrees centigrade, and molybdenum melts at two thousand six hundred and twenty two degrees centigrade. So, you know, we've some idea. Yes, I see now just what John found. I wonder if he was excited. Yes, that planet must be full of it. Full of it! It's a veritable gold mine!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Maitland and Carol clutch their heads

Dialogue.Line: Sensorites!
They're here. On the ship.
Come on, Barbara. Let's find them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go quietly past where John is sleeping, through a room into another corridor, then up to a door

Dialogue.Line: Where do you suppose this leads?
I don't know. Let's find out. Needn't come if you don't want to.
Nonsense.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian waves his hand in front of the electric eye, the door opens
The Sensorites step out in front of them. Ian grabs a metal tool from a cupboard

Dialogue.Line: Open the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara does so and they back out again

Dialogue.Line: Go and find Maitland. Ask him how to lock these doors.
But Ian.
Go on. Don't worry about me. Go on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door opens and the Sensorites step out. Ian keeps backing away, into another room

Dialogue.Line: Just tell me, how do we lock the doors? Please, try and concentrate.
The sick member of the crew. Try him.
He'll be in no condition to help.
Do as I say.
John. Show me how to lock the doors. The Sensorites are on the ship. We must stop them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She helps him out into the corridor as Ian is backing into it. Ian raises his weapon

Dialogue.Line: Ian, no.
Why not? How else can I keep these creatures off?
Well, do you need to keep them off? Have they actually attacked you? Come on, John. Lock the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: John waves his hand in front of a lower electric eye

Dialogue.Line: They can't open now.
It's strange they didn't harm you.
No.
I think they were as frightened of me as I was of them.
They're not very aggressive, are they.
No.
Come on, let's get back to the others.
The others! The other way! The Sensorites can get through that way!
Susan mustn't go with them.
There can't be air outside the spaceship.
You can't stop them.
We must!
Come with me, Barbara.
Don't. They'll only harm her or kill her if you try and interfere.
And if we do nothing, she'll die.
Do you intend to try out the Doctor's theory that they can't see in the dark?
Why not? It's all we have.
Go back.
Don't interfere, please.
The young girl has agreed to go with us. She will not be harmed. Why do you follow us now?
She must not go with you.
They are not carrying any weapons, yet I am frightened of them.
Do not come any nearer.
We want to talk to you.
We have no wish to harm you in any way.
I said talk, not fight.
Intruders from other planets always say they wish to talk, but all they mean to do is destroy.
Ian, please let me go with them. Because I can use telepathy, they trust me.
You're not going with them, Susan, and that's final.
Why? It's suspicion that's making them enemies. You don't understand the Sensorites.
Do you think I don't understand? Trust is a two-sided affair.
You're putting us all in danger.
If you go with them, then they will have all the advantage.
But they only want to talk to me.
I'm sorry, Susan, but I don't believe you have the ability to represent us. That's all.
Stop treating me like a child.
You will do as you're told, Susan. Come here.
I'm sorry, Grandfather, I can't do it.
This instant!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan steps forward

Dialogue.Line: We must stun them with the hand rays.
Now, Chesterton.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian switches the lights off, and in the twilight the Sensorites drop their weapons and flail about

Dialogue.Line: You were absolutely right, Doctor. They're helpless in the dark.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian picks up the weapons

Dialogue.Line: Susan, go and join Carol. Wait there. I want to talk to you.
Give us back the light.
The light, the light. I'm afraid. Afraid. Please, help us.
Put on the light, Chesterton. You could have been left here in the darkness. We have power over you, but we don't intend to use it. Only in our defence.
What do you want?
Nothing that isn't ours.
You stole the lock from our ship. You also threatened to take us prisoner.
We must ask for new orders.
What's that? Speak up!
I must refer this matter to the Sense Sphere.
Well?
You must be patient.
Oh, I won't put up with this nonsense. If they try anything, put the light out again.
All right, I will.
Dictated to by petty thieves and my own grandchild!
I wonder what that thing is that they put up to their foreheads, Barbara. Do you think if we did it, we could read each other's minds? Hey, Barbara.
Sorry, I was thinking. You know, I've never seen the Doctor so angry.
Oh, yes. Susan set him off, didn't she. The Sensorites must have hypnotised her in some way.
No, I don't think so. She's just growing up, Ian.
What is all this, setting yourself against me, hmm?
I didn't, Grandfather.
Oh, I know you thought you were doing your best, child, in the circumstances, but I think I'm a better judge of that.
Well, I have opinions too.
My dear girl, the one purpose in growing old is to accumulate knowledge and wisdom, and to help other people.
So I'm to be treated like a silly little child.
If you behave like one, yes.
Oh, look, Grandfather. I understand the Sensorites. They're timid little people. Because their minds and mine can communicate sometimes, they trust me.
Yes, and I assure you we shall make good use of that fact, but not without discussions. You will not make decisions on your own accord. Now, do you understand? Is that quite clear? Well, is it?
Look, I'm not saying I'm as clever as you, of course I'm not. But I won't be pushed aside. I'm not a child anymore, Grandfather. I'm not.
Oh, Susan, Susan.
Why do you make her unhappy?
We can read the misery in her mind.
Yes, and it's a good thing you can't read the anger in mine. In all the years my granddaughter and I have been travelling, we have never had an argument. And now you have caused one.
All right, Grandfather, I'll do as you tell me.
Good, good. Now let's work together and see if we can't get the lock of the Tardis back, hmm?
We have orders from the First Elder.
Is he your ruler?
Yes.
He says we are to listen to you and to transmit your words to him.
Very well, I'd like to talk to him, face to face. I want to arrange the release of this spaceship. Tell him we're not pirates or plunderers. There's only one treasure we desire from him.
What is that?
Freedom.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carol is stroking his hair when he suddenly sits up

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's all right, John. I'm here.
The voices. I can hear them.
I know.
In here. The voices. Afraid. Begging me.
John. John, do you know who I am?
You're good. The Sensorites, they want me to forget. All the voices begging me and imploring me to forget.
John's just woken up.
You look much better, John. Much better. We'll soon have you as good as new.
I don't like the voices. I want to have silence in my head.
You're going to be all right, John. Try not to upset yourself.
No. Silence. Silence.
It's no use, is it. He might as well be dead.
That's foolish, Carol.
Oh, is it? Look at him. Listen to him. Can you imagine what it's like being in love with someone, to look at them, to see them and know they've been destroyed.
You're going down to the Sense Sphere with John and some of the others. They're going to cure him.
Oh, it's no use. It's too late.
You're good.
And you can do something for John? Really?
Yes, in time.
And that's the whole point, isn't it. How long? You're asking Barbara and Maitland to stay on the spaceship while we go down to the Sense Sphere.
We cannot trust you without some safeguard.
But you're asking us to trust you.
We shall prove trust by curing the man called John.
Well I don't like this splitting up.
Well, I don't mind, Ian.
Well I do. It always leads to trouble.
We cannot agree to any other arrangement.
Then we accept.
Oh, very well then. And how do we get down to this Sense Sphere? There's no air outside the ship.
A craft will be made available to you.
Before we make this journey, one or two questions.
There's time. The craft has not arrived yet.
These discs you wear round your neck. You press them to your forehead and you speak or hear through your mind, hmm?
Yes.
Otherwise, you communicate as we do.
Yes.
Yes, I see. Quite remarkable. Then you use telepathy to blanket out the minds of the spaceship's crew, hmm?
Gently, Grandfather. Don't antagonise them.
I merely want to know why you attacked Maitland and the others.
Ten years ago, five human beings landed on the Sense Sphere. Our planet welcomed them. Their minds were closed against us, although we sensed they thought our planet was a rich one.
Yes, rich in minerals, yes, quite. Go on.
Then the five men quarrelled. Two of the humans took off in a ship. It exploded a mile in the atmosphere.
What happened to the other three men?
We imagine they hid themselves aboard, then fought the other two for control. Anyway, all were killed.
Yes, but that still doesn't explain why you attacked Maitland and the others.
Ever since that day of the explosion in the sky, our people have been dying in greater numbers every year.
Yes, some kind of disease I imagine, Chesterton.
Maybe.
Could be as simple as scarlet fever.
And yet you're allowing us to visit your planet?
Our people are dying, and the First Elder says he senses great knowledge in you.
Ah ha! I thought so. Yes, yes, yes, some kind of bargaining ahead of us.
The craft is approaching.
Well I suppose it's worth it, Doctor, if we get the lock of the Tardis back.
Yes, provided we can produce our side of the bargain. That's the whole point of the issue. Well, my dear. Reluctant as I am to leave you, I'm afraid we have no alternative.
Oh, I shall be all right. I'm more worried about you.
Oh, I shall manage. Come along my boy. Susan.
Sorry about this, Barbara.
I keep telling you I shall be all right.
All right.
Susan.
Yes?
Look, I know how you feel, but your grandfather loves you.
Yes, I know.
Be patient. We're all on your side really, you know.
Susan. We can't do without you. Can we?
Well, we're all ready now.
I will stay on this ship. You must proceed to the Sense Sphere. The First Elder awaits you.

Scenes.Scene: Palace of the Elders - Reception room

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Three Sensorites are present. The First Elder has crossed sashes, the Second Elder a single sash, and the City Administrator a dark collar

Dialogue.Line: But I have already made my decision.
The deaths of our people will increase.
You cannot prove that.
The deaths began at the time of the last visit of human beings. Why should we welcomed to our planet the same creatures who have been the means of our destruction.
I am the ruler of this planet, am I not?
Of course.
Then what is the point of a ruler if he's not allowed to rule? I have decided to invite these humans because I hope to use them to end the deaths of our own people.
But how?
I will explain. Sometimes one must use fire to make fire.

The First Elder makes a wise decision. In one degree I confess I am anxious. These creatures, these Earth people, are loud and ugly things. Why could we not have met them in the desert or in the mountains?
It is a failure of all beings that they judge through their own eyes. To them, we may appear to be ugly. What we must create between us is trust. That is why I have invited them to my palace.

But are we sure these Earth creatures are beings as you say? There are animals in the deserts and mountains, but we do not invite them in to our palaces. Perhaps these Earth creatures are animals too?

Do not underestimate them. Do we possess a spaceship that can cross the barriers of the universe? And this small mechanism, which my men brought to me, looks like an ordinary lock but in point of fact is an electronic miracle which reveals a mind of science far beyond ours. And this new arrival known as the Doctor. His mind was quick to realise our weakness in the dark and use it against us, but, I would remind you, not unfairly. Merely to protect the girl called Susan. Well, and what does our city administrator say?
Sir, you were elected to lead our people because of your great brain. I would not dare to question your actions.
No opinion can be worse sometimes than a very dogmatic one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The First Elder leaves

Dialogue.Line: You need not fear me. You may speak your mind.
I am cautious. You are his second opinion, yet he makes his decisions without you.
He makes a wise decision.
Based entirely upon trust. Do you trust these Earth creatures? No more do I.
The decision of the First Elder cannot be set aside.
I would not suggest such a thing. His mind is pure. We are realists. That is why I have beamed the disintegrator to this room.
Without permission? You are presumptuous.

I am the city's administrator. It is my duty to protect the one who rules. Can you say that these Earth creatures will not use force? I am only guarding the First Elder. One suspicious act and the disintegrator will destroy them.
Very well. But you will do nothing further until I have considered the matter.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: leaves

Dialogue.Line: I shall not wait. We will not be safe until these Earth creatures are dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Strolling through the city, past a fountain

Dialogue.Line: I'm glad to have left those silent people.
Earth people are not popular.
Because your people have been dying?
Yes.
It must be explained to them. The disease, if that's what it is, isn't anybody's fault. Besides, there's cures and preventives.
You mentioned explaining to the people. You must not speak to them. You are forbidden to talk to the lower caste.
Lower caste? Do you have such distinctions?
Yes. How else can we tell what each man is best fitted to do? The Elders think and rule, the Warriors fight, the Sensorites work and play.
You make it sound so very simple.
And all are happy.
But some are happier than others, eh?
I do not understand. There is no disgrace in being in any of the castes. It is simply what one is best fitted for.
They're near us now.
It's all right, John. I'm here.
The evil minds.
He knows something.
Oh, it's just a jumble of words.
No, Carol, no. Remember, his mind is open. He can tell the difference between good and evil people. He's trying to tell us something.
Come on. Come on. Come on.
Is everything prepared?
I must test the impulse circuits. Ready to receive power.
Here is the firing key. Beam the disintegrator to the reception room at the Palace of the Elders.
Ready.
Three places have been assigned to the Earth creatures. Horizontal lines four
Four.
Seven and nine.
Nine. The vertical positions?
X A two.
X A two.
X B three.
X B three. And the last?
X C four.
X C four. What part of the body do you want the beam to strike?
In each case, to the heart.
Are the hearts of the human creatures on the right or left side of their bodies, or in the centre as in ours?
I do not know.
Then I will aim the beam at the centre of the chest in each case.
And that will prove fatal?

Yes. Two, eight, seven. The disintegrator is beamed and ready. They are just entering the corridor to the reception room now. Impulses working correctly. They are just entering the reception room. This switch here turns on the beam.
How can you judge their movements so correctly, Engineer?
The palace is defended with electrothermal couples. We trace their movements by the heat of their bodies.
And you can tell exactly when they move into their places in the reception room?
With absolute accuracy.
Then when they are seated, kill them.
Very well, I agree.
You can do it?
Yes. The man John can be exactly as he used to be, but it will take time. Conduct him to one of the rest rooms. Say that my orders are that he must be treated.
I must go with him, because he needs me.
Very well. You will be given a room near him.
Thank you. Come on, John.
Good. He is a good man. Not like.
Not like who, John?
He is good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Carol and John leave

Dialogue.Line: Thank you for being so understanding.
It doesn't alter the fact that you're responsible for his condition. I think it's utterly disgraceful.
Please, do not condemn before you know the facts.
Facts? What facts, sir?
Grandfather, please don't.
Very well.
Please sit at the places set for you.
They are just taking their positions.
Get ready to fire.
Stop! Disconnect the disintegrator.
Why?
Because they are reasonable, they are civilised.
They are Earth creatures, and dangerous to us.
I tell you, they're talking with the First Elder, and in a most friendly fashion. We need not fear them.
Not whilst we have the disintegrator. It is beamed to their positions. They can be destroyed in a second.
But they will not be. Dismantle the machine.
I say that the trust that we give to each other, we cannot show to these Earth creatures.
And I order that the machine be dismantled. Give me the firing key.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Engineer hands it over

Dialogue.Line: I am doubtful about you. You question orders, you question authority. Take care lest my doubts are become realities.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Ian and Susan are being served refreshments

Dialogue.Line: If foreigners visited your planet with intention to steal, what would you do? Would you imprison them? Would you kill them? The man John was like the other humans who came here. He became so excited when he found that our planet contained a valuable ore that his mind just opened up and shouted out the secret to us.
Molybdenum.

That is correct. He thought of a fleet of spaceships to come here and mine the metal and transport it back to his own planet. We saw the pictures he formed in his mind, and we saw that it was the end of our way of life. We had no alternative but to imprison him and his friends in orbit round the Sense Sphere.
Yes, but that's no reason for driving him out of his mind.

Happened only, I assure you, because of his excitement. His mind had no reserve, no defence. We caused the others to sleep, but he heard the full power of our voices in his brain. Stop. Do not drink. Why do you offer insult to our guests? Why do you not give them the same food and drink that I am given? Who ordered this? The city Administrator?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The serving Sensorite nods

Dialogue.Line: You will bring them the crystal water and take the other away.
Tell me, what exactly is the difference?

In the yellow mountains that surround this city, I discovered a pure spring. Very unusual in this planet. I believe the water holds special qualities, so I have flagons of it stored for the use of the Elders.
And this one?
Is very well refined. We are very proud of our aqueduct. It lies beneath the city.
I hope you won't be offended if I drink some. I'm very thirsty. (drinks)
As long as you taste of the crystal water. It is very fine. None of the Elders drink anything else.
Vintage water.
This fruit is delicious. It tastes like peaches.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The water is exchanged

Dialogue.Line: Now, sir, let us talk of the future. Our future.
We are being bound hand and foot and given to these people from Earth. Our leaders are grown weak.
I will follow you, the city Administrator. Command me.
I thank you for your loyalty. You shall have my confidence.
I gladly accept. I do not trust these Earth creatures.
The First and Second Elders are deceived. I question their leadership. If they do not change their attitude, they may have to give way to one of stronger thought and action.
Command me.
For the moment, I am glad of your loyalty. The time for action will not be far away.

Episodes.Episode: Episode Four - A Race Against Death

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian is lying face down on the floor

Dialogue.Line: Why has it happened to him and not to us?
Can you do anything for him?
The disease hits all manner of people. Suddenly, without warning.
Never the Elders?
No.
It's incredible. The build-up in body temperature. This disease, as you call it, is it contagious?
No.
I wonder. Is it a germ in the air?
Grandfather, it doesn't seem like a disease at all.
I agree with you.
We've done everything together. We've come from the spaceship together, we've come through the city together.
Yes, yes, yes.
This room. The fruit.
No. No, no, no, no, no. You had some of it.
Oh, yes.
I know. He drank a different kind of water. It's the water!
Then why do not all who drink the aqueduct water die?
Well, it depends on their resistance. In time, of course, all will succumb.
You cannot be sure of this.
No, I can't. This is all we have to go on. Send for your servant, please.
His eyes are opening, Grandfather.
(very hoarse) Susan.
It's all right, Chesterton. Rest quietly. This isn't a disease, it's more like poison.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The servant arrives and bows

Dialogue.Line: Oh, go to your scientists now. I want some sodium chloride and I want it quickly.
What happened to me?
Hush, Ian. Just rest.
Do you wish your companion to stay here?
Please, please.
Bring some covers.
Now, sir, your indulgence.
I am distressed by this tragedy. What can I do to be of assistance?
Well, we must make sure no one drinks anything but the crystal water.
Agreed.
Fine. And can I work with your scientists?
They will be honoured.
Splendid, splendid.
How long has he got?
I hear the distress in your mind. I respond to it. I wish I could be more reassuring.
How long?
From the first symptoms, no one has lived longer than the third day.
As long as that? Then we have time. I have chemicals and equipment on my ship. Return the lock and I promise you, sir, I will not only cure my young friend but all your people.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The servant returns

Dialogue.Line: Ah, good.
I must discuss this matter with the Second Elder.
Well do not delay any longer than is necessary, please. Thank you. Now, salt and water, Susan. An old-fashioned remedy but I'm sure it'll serve. Thank you. Now, my boy.
Ian. Ian, try and sit up.
Come along, old chap.
Feeling very weak, Doctor.
Yes, now I want you to drink all of this. It isn't going to be pleasant, but it's all for your own good.
Drink.
That's it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian drinks, splutters at the saltiness

Dialogue.Line: Will they let me into my ship?
Now be guided by me in this matter. The one they call the Doctor may not be sincere.
But his friend is dying.
Or pretending to die. Then you let the Doctor into his spaceship.
Would he leave his friends at our mercy?
But who knows what power he has in the ship? Once inside it, we may be at his mercy.
Well, I believe in him.
The Doctor may go away to fetch an army of human beings and a fleet of spaceships.
This is a terrible picture you paint. Do you mistrust them as much as all that?
I do not trust them as much as you, so I advise caution.
I will think of your advice, and weigh up the matter.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: John is in a chair, with a metal crown of electrodes on his head

Dialogue.Line: How may I help the city Administrator?
Why is this creature here?
We are clearing his mind.
On whose orders?
The First Elder.
It would have been better to kill him than cure him, Scientist.
Leave us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scientist leaves

Dialogue.Line: Once again you question the voice of authority.
Sir, the Elders rule this planet while I am only responsible for this city, yet I will do everything within my power to protect and defend that city.
Be careful your power is not taken from you.
These intruders threaten us all. This creature is being cured!
Yes, we fulfil a promise.
At any moment you will put them in their ship and let them go! This is madness!
One more insolent word from you and I shall ask that your collar of office be taken from you. This man is to be cured. As for the other one.
Which other one?
The one known as Ian Chesterton.
These are absurd names they all have. None of them wear any signs of authority or badges of position. How are we to distinguish them? What is wrong with the other one?
He has caught the disease. Their commander, the Doctor, believes our water supply is to blame.
What a brilliant scheme. Evil, but undoubtedly brilliant.
Explain.
To attack our confidence in one of the necessities. There is nothing wrong with our water supply. Nothing at all. This is a trick to get us at their mercy.
Evil. Evil.
Do you see? Even this half-broken creature here admits the truth.
I must warn the First Elder.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Second Elder leaves

Dialogue.Line: No, no. Evil is here.
He cannot hear you. Your mind is closed by the machine. Your voice is not believed.
You are my enemy.
I am the enemy of all Earth creatures, and any Sensorite who defends them shall be swept away.
I must warn them of your evil. I must. I must!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: John passes out

Dialogue.Line: Your brain is too weak to harm me.
How's John? Oh, I am sorry. I thought you were one of the scientists.
You can see my collar of office. I am the city Administrator.
Yes, I'm sorry, but when your backs are turned, it's very difficult to see. I don't know what we'd all do if you changed your badges and sashes. We wouldn't be able to tell you apart.
I have never thought of that.
John?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor's anger is making the First Elder cringe. Ian is on a sheepskin covered couch nearby

Dialogue.Line: But he'll die!
No noise! I beg of you.
Why can't you make up your mind?

Just look at that young man. I've done all I can for him at the moment. Given him salt and water. He's been coughing his heart out. I must have chemicals and equipment. His death will be your fault, and yours alone.
Very well, I
Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They commune telepathically

Dialogue.Line: What is it now?
I can't hear very clearly. Their minds aren't open to me.
Do you really mean you can hear their minds talking, Susan?
Yes, but it's not very distinct.
Doctor, I cannot allow you to go to your ship.
Don't set yourself against me.
There is a laboratory here. You may prove your poisoned water theory there, or not at all.
You fool!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Sensorites cringe

Dialogue.Line: Grandfather, please! They think you're attacking them. We're sorry. There's so much about your planet we don't understand.
It's inhuman.
Grandfather.
Just monstrous.
We didn't mean to use sound as a weapon. We didn't even know sound hurt you.
Very well, but please be careful in future. I wish to see regular reports on the progress of this theory.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The First Elder leaves, Second Elder stays

Dialogue.Line: Theory?
Grandfather, please!
I know we have no alternative, but such outrageous behaviour! Oh, forget it, child. Now, I want you to stay here and act as nurse. Watch his pulse rate, will you, and let me know immediately
Doctor. What's happened to me?
How are you feeling?
My throat's still sore.
Any pains elsewhere?
No, but I feel very giddy.

Yes, well, you just rest there quietly. Yes, we'll let him have all the crystal water he wants, and if his breathing gets febrile, artificial respiration. Now, sir. Your laboratory. And I only hope there's time to save him.
The Second Elder has given the firing pin to the Chief of Warriors. I saw him.
Then the disintegrator is no longer of any use to us. How can we destroy these crea

Dialogue.Stage Direction: First Elder enters

Dialogue.Line: Shh.
I have placed our laboratory at the disposal of the man called the Doctor. See to it that he is given every cooperation.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: First Elder leaves

Dialogue.Line: Your witness. These creatures are defeating us with smiles and gentle words. Our leaders listen and agree. Soon we shall all be slaves.
What can we do?
Bring the Second Elder to me. Alone. The girl Carol gave me an idea. How would you recognise the Second Elder at a distance?
By the sash he wears.
Bring the Second Elder to me at the disintegrator room.
Yes.
We must match cunning with cunning.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lots of twirly glass and rubber hoses on a table, and John safely out of sight over on the right of our screen

Dialogue.Line: Yes, well, I have to say, very comprehensive. Now, gentlemen, time is not on our side. I believe your people have been dying because there is atropine poison in the aqueduct water. Now, allow me. I've made a few notes here which might interest you. Now these are the symptoms. Atropine causes dilation of the blood vessels. Temperature rises and pulse rate becomes very rapid. A rash may appear. The mouth and throat both become extremely dry. Now what we have to do is this, gentlemen. Isolate the poison and then prescribe the remedy.
We give you our assistance.
Good.
Although we have tested the water already.
Yes, well then we must try again.
Over here is a sample of the aqueduct water.
Ah, yes. You know, a strange thing here is, not all your people died.
Three in every ten. Last year it was two in every ten.
Yes, of course some may be able to resist it or perhaps some of the water is good.
But all the water is the same.
Yes, but surely from different outlets?
There are ten districts in the city, but only one source.
Well, gentlemen, there's a poison at work here. I know the signs. Now what you must do is to test samples from each and every district. Where did that come from?
This palace. It is district ten.

I see. Well now, I suggest that you sample that bottle, and mark it and then start keeping records. And there's not a moment to lose. And remember, I want samples from all the outlying districts. It's imperative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And so the testing starts, as Ian becomes delirious. District after district comes back negative for contaminants, until -

Dialogue.Line: This one! I've found it. And just as I suspected, atropine poison. That's why your people have been dying off.
But why were some of the districts negative?
Because it varies from place to place, and when you made your tests, you didn't discover it.
And can the Doctor discover a cure?
He says so. Caffeine citrate is the antidote.
Remarkable man. Remarkable.
I have an appointment, then I shall return to the laboratory.
Give my Doctor the congratulations on the progress.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Second Elder leaves, and First Elder goes over to Ian's sickbed or couch

Dialogue.Line: He's much easier now.
The Doctor has had some success. A remedy will be available soon.
Thank goodness. Ian. Ian, you're going to be all right.
They are coming now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Second Elder enters

Dialogue.Line: Why are we meeting here?
Hold him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two Sensorites grab the Second Elder

Dialogue.Line: You will be punished for this offence.
I advise you to answer my questions. Your family group is also in my power.
What have you done with them?
Nothing so far. Has the Doctor completed his experiments?
Yes.
And the antidote is to be given to the young man Ian?
Yes.
And then to our people who are also ill?
Yes.
I do not believe there is an antidote. The young man pretends to be ill. The Doctor pretends to cure him, and then he will kill us all with the poison he has made.
That's not true! Our scientists have worked with him. They say
Silence! You are a traitor to our people. You are not worthy to wear this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He pulls off the Elder's sash, and his own collar, then puts the sash on himself

Dialogue.Line: What are you going to do?
This so-called antidote must be stopped. The people will obey their Elders.
The First Elder has approved the antidote.
And yet it will be stopped. The Second Elder will suppress it.
I will not!
I wear your sash of office. Who is to know that I am not the Second Elder now? Bind him. Keep him here.
You're tired out, Doctor.
Yes, but a happy tiredness, my dear. How's our friend?
Oh, he's improving, but he still seems to go back sometimes to that old state of confusion.
Yes, you must expect that. Ah, my friend. You've prepared the antidote?
Yes, Doctor.
Splendid. Now I think we ought to start making this in large quantities. Will you please see that that goes to the First Elder's room? Give it to my granddaughter, Susan.
I'll send a messenger immediately.
Yes, well now we shall soon be off this planet.
When John's cured. There's no quick antidote for him.
Oh, courage, my dear. Courage. Of course, I'm rather baffled with this atropine poison, because it only seems to appear in one part of the city or rather one reservoir at a time. It's curious.
Yes, but you've discovered an antidote now.
Oh, yes, that's a cure all right, but then why cure something when we can stamp it out, hmm?
Enemies.
What's that, my friend?
Plotting.
He's more coherent now, but it's as if he was living in a dream world where he's surrounded by enemies.
Enemies. Yes. Making plots.
I don't know. He might be more lucid, you know, than one should imagine. Now I'm going off on an expedition, and I want you to take note of what he says.
Listen to John.
You see, he knows his name. Now you stay with him. I think he's getting better, and I'm sure you're going to have a great future between you, later on. Now, after my little exploration...
Where are you going, Doctor?
I'm going to find the First Elder, Scientist, rather, and we're going off on an exploration. It isn't dangerous, of course. But when I have solved my problem I'm sure we shall all be out of trouble.
Supposing your disguise is seen through?
You must remember that the First and Second Elders are well known only to those in powerful positions. The people see them rarely, and mostly at a distance.
I greet the Second Elder.
I return your greeting, Scientist.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Scientist starts to leave

Dialogue.Line: Success!
Yes. Scientist, come here. Where are you going?
The man from the spaceship, the Doctor, has found a cure. Poison was in our water supply. Here is the antidote.
You take it to the young Earth creature who is ill?
Yes.
Give it to me. I will deliver it. Return to your laboratory.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Scientist leaves

Dialogue.Line: If this Doctor has found a cure
It's a trick. They are trying to poison us all. I will prove it to you. They say without the antidote the young man will die. I say he will live because he is pretending.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And he throws the vial to the floor, where it smashes

Dialogue.Line: This will prove it one way or the other.
Why hasn't the antidote arrived yet?
I do not know.
Doctor must have run into a snag, Susan. It's not always possible to do these things at the snap of a finger.
I'm going to find out why. May I do that?
Yes. I will have you conducted to the laboratory. Go with this servant, and give my respects to the senior scientist.
Here is the entrance to the aqueduct.
It's very gloomy.
All our attempts to light it end in failure for one reason or another.
But that must make it rather difficult for you. The Sensorites dislike darkness, don't they?
We avoid this place. We have no reason to go down to the aqueduct anyway.
Well, it may be because you've neglected it that the water's become poisoned.
Shall we return now?
Return? I don't want to return. I haven't just come here for a look. I'm going in there.
No! You must not.
And why?
You will not be able to see.
Oh, but I have a torch.
There are monsters in there.
Indeed? Are there?
Yes, we've heard them.
And not seen them?
No, but they are there. The noise is terrifying.
Yes, I think you should return to the laboratory. I shall be all right. Leave it to me, will you? I assure you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Scientist leaves

Dialogue.Line: How very convenient. Yes. Noise and darkness. The two things the Sensorites dislike. There's more in this than meets the eye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan has given Ian an injection

Dialogue.Line: I cannot understand why the Second Elder did not bring the antidote here.
Well I managed to get some more. That's all that really matters. Thank you. Now, no running around for a bit, Ian.
Yes, Matron. Actually, I'm quite happy to stay here. I feel as though someone has given me a good going over with a hammer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Scientist enters

Dialogue.Line: I attend you, sire.
My orders have not been complied with. I asked for regular reports. Where have you been?
Forgive me, sir. The Doctor asked me to take him to the aqueduct.
Why?
He said that that was where the root of the trouble lay. I couldn't stop him. He sent me away and said he was going in.
Did you not warn him?
Yes, but he took no notice.
Warn him of what?
The aqueduct. It's inhabited by monsters.
What? Why did you let him go down there?
I couldn't stop him.
We must get him out. Haven't you got someone you can send down there to help him?
The caverns are dark. We are helpless.
Take some light with you then.
Other expeditions have tried and failed. Most of our men do not return, and those that do speak of terrible things.
Well, I'll have to go myself and
No you won't.
We can't stay here, Susan.
You're too ill, Ian.
I'm not that ill.
All right. We'll need someone to show us the way.
I beg you to change your minds. You cannot save your friend.
We'll never know till we try, will we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Scientist leads them out, Ian leaning on Susan

Dialogue.Line: These people have fine qualities. The Second Elder and I have misjudged them, and I will tell him so.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He uses his telepathy device

Dialogue.Line: I hear you, sir. I hear you.
Someone's mind is in communication with yours? Whose is it? The First Elder?
Give me the mind transmitter.
Do you think I'm a fool? You can hear, but you cannot speak your mind without this. What is he saying to you?
I refuse to tell you.
Think of your family group. Its safety depends upon you.

It is the First Elder. He says we have misjudged the human beings from Earth. He's saying the one called the Doctor has gone down into the viaduct, that the young man and the girl called Susan have gone to rescue him. He is asking why I don't reply.
No one, no one can come out of the aqueduct alive. The one known as the Doctor is near death. The other two approach death. I see victory for all my plans!
Is this it?
Yes. Take this. It's a radio-electric light.
Thank you. Ian, how do you feel? If you don't want to go any further, just say.
No, I'm fine. Come on.
What is it, Ian?
We must find him.
Are you all right?
Yes.
Lean on me.
Keep away!
Grandfather!
He's unconscious. Here, help me to get him out of here.
Look at the state he's in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The back of the Doctor's jacket is in shreds

Dialogue.Line: Don't worry about that. Collect up his things. We don't want to hang around here. It's going away.
Ian, what do you think this is?
I don't know. Part of an old lighting system I suppose. Don't worry about that now. Let's get him out of here before that thing comes back.
Can't just give up. You know the aqueduct. Surely you can help them in some way?
I regret it is impossible.
You have no conception of what extreme sound does to us. It stuns the brain and paralyses the nerves.
And in the darkness we're helpless anyway. Our warriors will be more of a hindrance than a help.
Is there no hope for them, then?
Let us speak of your companion, the man John. The senior scientist told me that he's making excellent progress. The final treatment will be given today.
Thank you.
You are sad for the friends you have lost. Rejoice for the friend who is being returned to you. Scientist, you will report to me on your progress.
I will, sir.
Those poor people.
Just look at this coat. It's ruined.
Those look like claw marks. Strange they didn't reach your skin.
Yes, strange indeed when you realise that I was at the mercy of that creature. It was so dark in there it was invisible and it knocked me to the ground.
Are you sure you didn't see it?
No, no, no. Something hit me under the heart and it was most unpleasant. It was a good thing I sent you that antidote. Otherwise I might have been in a much worse state than I was.
We didn't get the antidote. I had to go all the way back to the laboratory and get some more.
What?
Yes. Surrounded by enemies.
Then it's true. True. The water, and those monsters in there, and now it appears that there's someone among the Sensorites that bear us ill-will. That's two separate enemies.
Don't you mean three?

No, no, no, no. No, don't mistake me. The water and those monsters are distinctly connected. I've more or less solved that problem. But this Sensorite who's against us is a much greater danger. Now I suggest we go back and try and find out which one it is.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Sensorite watches them leave

Dialogue.Line: Treachery.
He keeps on saying the same things.
A plot. I must warn you.
I'm sure he's discovered something or he's overheard someone and he's trying to tell us.
Yes. Tell you. Warn you.
You see?
It must be illusion. Our society is based upon trust. Treason or secret plotting is impossible.
That's rather a sweeping statement.
But why should a Sensorite make any secret plans against anyone? We have the perfect society. All are contented.
Some people always want more than others.
That is a human value, surely.
Perhaps. Rest quietly now, John. It won't be long. (to Scientist) You were trying to explain something to me earlier.
We discovered long ago that in our brains there were many different compartments or divisions. When fear or alarm is at work, that section becomes open, a veil is lifted. Do you understand?
Yes.

That is what happened to the man John. But the veil will not lower itself. Thus he is constantly afraid. Even when he's at peace, when he's asleep for example, the body says one thing, the brain the other. That's his condition, utter confusion.
And this treatment you're giving him is in order to close down that veil?
Yes. Not permanently, of course, or he would step into danger without concern. The veil must function normally again.
It's rather like an eyelid, isn't it. These shutters over my eyes.
Yes. To see all the time is not a good thing. Now, we must begin.
Yes. I'll be here all the time, John.
Carol.
Yes, that's right.
I must tell you, but it's so difficult.
Soon you'll be able to tell me all you've found out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Second Elder is being untied, but the Administrator still wears his sash of office

Dialogue.Line: There is no mistake, City Administrator. I saw the Doctor and the other two leave the aqueduct. I hear them talking. They are suspicious.
The creature John is nearly cured. He too can speak against me. We are nearly surrounded by our enemies.
You will be uncovered as a traitor and a criminal.
Silence.
What are we to do?
These Earth creatures are working to destroy the Sensorite nation. Their pleasant smile conceals sharp teeth, their soft words hide deadly threats.
Please, don't listen.
And who opposes them? Weak and timid creatures like this Second Elder here, whose sash I wear.
Thief.
Whimpering betrayer of our people. Coward! I should imprison you in some room wherein no light can shine, and fill that room with noise!
Do it, then. Finish with me.

Not yet. Remember, I hold your family group. First you shall do something for me. Summon the Senior Warrior with your mind transmitter. Tell him to bring the firing key of the disintegrator and meet you in the forecourt of the palace.
No.
Remember your family group.
Very well.

I shall be listening. Stand over him. Stab him if he sends his mind to anyone other than the Senior Warrior. Now send this thought. Senior Warrior, this is the Second Elder. Go on! Send it! Good. He's answering. Tell him to bring the firing key and meet you in the courtyard of the Palace of the Elders. That is enough. I shall keep the appointment you have made. The Senior Warrior shall know me by the sash I wear. Your sash. Guard him well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Administrator leaves

Dialogue.Line: Why do you listen to him? Why do you follow him?
He will not betray our people, nor surrender our planet.
He will bring us all down. All of us.
Be silent!
All of us.
You've been exerting yourself, boy, and naturally you're weak.
He can rest now though, can't he, Grandfather. We'll force him to.
I wish you two'd stop fussing over me.
Now, now, you must do as you're told, and that is that. Isn't that one of the Elders?
It's the Second Elder. He's only got one sash.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They see the Warrior hand the key over to the 'Elder'

Dialogue.Line: Take it easy. I want a word with him. I say, you, sir. Sir, I'd like a word with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor follows him off, and the Warrior leaves in the opposite direction

Dialogue.Line: It's a funny place down here, isn't it?
What about up there? I wonder how Barbara's getting on?
I wish she were down here with us.
I wish we were up there in the Tardis and away from here. Still, I know what you mean. Hey, why don't we ask the First Elder if Barbara can come down and join us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor returns

Dialogue.Line: Yes.
Most extraordinary. He ran away from me!
(laughs) That must have looked funny. Flip, flap, flip, flap.
I can assure you he was very mobile, my child. Come along, let's get into the First Elder's room. Come along.
Why have you not retied his hands? (the Engineer obeys) Now, now I have the power.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Second Elder shrugs off the Engineer and takes the key from the Administrator. He then bends it against the edge of the console

Dialogue.Line: Stop him, you fool!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's a brief struggle, and the Engineer knocks out the Second Elder

Dialogue.Line: He has broken it!
The Second Elder is dead!
The only other firing key is in the possession of the First Elder!
Then we shall have to give up. We must leave the city, hide in the mountains.
No, no. Don't be foolish. The death of the Second Elder can help us, not condemn us. We must act quickly. You know the man called the Doctor?
Yes.
You can describe him?
Yes.
Good. Then I will outline my plan to you.
Yes, I have asked questions. The first supply of the antidote you sent, Doctor, was intercepted by my Second Elder, my advisor. He has since disappeared.
We saw him in the courtyard.
His behaviour is a mystery.
Yes, strange indeed, sir. I tried to talk to him and he ran away.
Yes. You still won't accept that he's done something bad.
I cannot. I selected him for office, but it is not pride which makes me defend my choice. I know that Sensorite. I trust him.
And yet you can't explain his actions.
A mystery does not mean that he is guilty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Sensorite enters with a cloak

Dialogue.Line: For the Doctor.
My dear sir. That's most civil of you. I ruined my jacket down in the aqueduct, but of course I have others on my ship. Thank you.
Very smart.
Beau Brummell always said I looked better in a cloak.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Administrator enters, wearing his proper collar

Dialogue.Line: The City Administrator wishes to speak?
Urgently, sir. A story has been put before me that you should hear.
Now?
It concerns the Second Elder and these Earth creatures.
Very well.
Enter.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior and the Engineer enter

Dialogue.Line: Tell your story.
Sir, the Second Elder is dead. He was killed in the courtyard. I saw the man who killed him.
The man?
Yes, sir. It was the man called the Doctor.
That's not true!
The Senior Warrior here has evidence. Speak.
I met the Second Elder in the courtyard, as he ordered me to. I gave him the firing key of the disintegrator. Then I saw the Doctor go after the Second Elder.
Yes, I did that, but I didn't kill him.
I saw you. You wrestled for possession of the firing key.
There is the firing key, bent as though in a struggle.
And finally, when the Second Elder resisted, you took an object from inside your coat, and struck him down and killed him.
This is a grave charge.
But obviously untrue, sir.
Why?
How did you recognise the Doctor?
His hair is different.
Yes.
So are his clothes.
Oh, yes, his clothes. You say that you saw him take an object from his pocket.
Yes.
You could see quite clearly? You're sure it was from his coat pocket?
I tell you yes! All the Sensorites know the Doctor by his

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stands, and poses grandly in his cloak

Dialogue.Line: The Doctor's coat is outside the aqueduct. You are lying.
Then, then it was a cloak he was wearing! Yes, it was. I'm sure of it now. It was a cloak.
I have just presented the Doctor with that cloak. Your story is a tissue of lies. Remove him.
I shall interview you myself.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior leads the Engineer away

Dialogue.Line: Sir, you must forgive his wild accusation, but I felt his story should be brought before you.
You acted correctly. What can have possessed my advisor?
The Second Elder, sir, was always opposed to our visitors. Perhaps he stole the firing key in order to attack them with the disintegrator?
I bet he stole our antidote too. He was our enemy.
A sad matter. But since he has deceived us, my sympathy shall not be wasted. As to his replacement.
I have his sash of office here, so that you may select a new advisor immediately.
Perhaps he ought not to look further than this room.
Yes. If he thought he got promotion because of us, he'd be a useful ally.
Just what I was thinking. Yes, of course, we have no wish to interfere in your affairs, but the City Administrator appears to have all the qualifications.
Well, what do you say? Can you accept such power, such authority?
My only ambition is to serve the Sensorite nation.

Then accept this sash. I make you my advisor. From now on you will be know as the Second Elder, second only on the Sense Sphere to me. And once this order is made, only a betrayal of trust can set it aside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Administrator takes of his neck band, and the First Elder puts the sash on him. But I'll still call him Administrator

Dialogue.Line: My new advisor and I have much to discuss. You will excuse us?
Certainly, sir. My companions and I will pay a visit to the man John, and note his progress.
Oh, you were going to ask about Barbara.
I don't think this is quite the moment. I'll ask later.
All right.
Oh, and congratulations.
When you address one of the Elders, you call him sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: John no longer wears the contraption on his head

Dialogue.Line: Now we shall know.
John. John?
Such a headache.
That will go quickly.
It's easing now. Carol. You're crying.
I'm all right, really I am. It's just that I haven't seen you smile for so long.
But we can't have you crying, can we. I'm all right now. I'm all right. That John's gone quite suddenly. Was it awful?
All that matters is how you are now.
What have I been like all this time?
Don't you remember?
Some things, but most of it seems a sort of grey cloud. I just remember that it seems a very long time.
Yes. Oh, John, I can't tell you how I feel. How glad.
It is indeed a time of happiness for both of you.
Oh, this is the scientist who cured you.
Then I have a lot to thank you for.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He holds out his hand

Dialogue.Line: What do you ask for?
We have a custom of shaking hands with someone, in friendship.
Then, I accept.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Ian and Susan enter

Dialogue.Line: Well, well. What a happy scene.
Do you remember us?
I remember you distinctly.
Well I'm Ian, and this is the Doctor, Susan's grandfather.
I'm glad to see you don't bear a grudge against the Sensorites for the past.
All that matters now is the present.
Splendid. Now sir, the antidote. I wonder if

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They move off out of shot

Dialogue.Line: I remember another girl.
Oh, that's Barbara. We both found you. She's up in the spaceship.
Oh I see.
John, all the time you were ill, you were trying to warn us of something.
There was a Sensorite who was dangerous. I must try and remember what happened.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Administrator sneaks in quietly

Dialogue.Line: I know there was a plot. Yes, that's it. Someone was plotting against you
And this Sensorite. Can you identify him?
No.
Is he in this room?
No. There was something particularly odd about his clothes, I remember. Exactly what
Yes, it must have been the Sensorite who just died.
Yes. I suppose it must.
The First Elder wishes to talk to the Doctor. You will inform him.
All right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Administrator leaves

Dialogue.Line: He's not very friendly.
Well, he's only just become Second Elder. I should think he's trying out his new authority.
I wouldn't like to cross him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Across the lab

Dialogue.Line: And what is this little collection of things here?
Left behind by the humans that were killed in the spaceship explosion.
I see.
Oh, look at these, Doctor. Family snapshots. Look.
Yes, now just a moment. This is rather important. This is a rough plan of the aqueduct.
One of the human beings was very interested in the aqueduct.
Is that so?
Grandfather, the First Elder wants to talk to you.
Oh, yes. I have a couple of questions for him.
This is only a sketch. I can let you have a plan in detail if you need.
Very valuable, very valuable.
The City Administrator can have no objection.
The City Administrator! Of course!
What about him? What about him?
John, you know you said that there was something odd about the Sensorite? Was it his collar?
Collar. Yes, that was it.
You see, the City Administrator. He was our enemy.
What, the one who's just been made the Second Elder?
Yes! When John was ill, he must have given himself away.
Yes. He was certainly pretty odd with me.
If this is true what you say, Susan, there's trouble ahead for us. That Sensorite has power now.
Yes, and the worst of it is, we gave him the power.
You were not to know that the Doctor had changed his coat. I managed your escape from prison and that is all that matters.
I am grateful, but what use am I now?
I still have a task for you. You are accomplished in mechanical matters.
Yes. What do you want me to do?
(holding weapons) Can you remove the mechanisms but leave them looking perfect from the outside?
Yes.
Then see to it.
It's no use telling him stories about the Second Elder, Doctor. We've got to give him proof.
Yes, I quite agree. And the only way to get that proof is to go back into the aqueduct. What about Susan?
Look, why don't you ask the First Elder if we can have Barbara down here again.
A good idea.
Gentlemen. Be seated.
Yes, thank you.
Well, sir, the Doctor and I have discussed this poison business, and we are convinced that your water supply is being deliberately poisoned.
Yes, and what we propose to do, sir, is to go down into the aqueduct, find your enemies and stop them.
Very well. But you will take light with you, and such arms as we can provide.
Thank you. We're making progress.
Barbara.
I wonder, sir, could I ask you a small favour?
Ask it.
We have a companion, a young lady, on the ship. Is it possible for her to be brought down here in the Sense Sphere?
It will be arranged.
Splendid, sir. Splendid.
I have brought the weapons, sir.
Ah. Thank you. Warrior. Instruct them as to their use.
It's done. I have arranged that the useless weapons shall be delivered to the humans. Hide yourself.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Engineer leaves

Dialogue.Line: What have you there?
It is the plan of the aqueduct, sir. The Doctor asked for it.
Give it to me. I will deliver it. Return to your duties.
Thank you, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scientist leaves

Dialogue.Line: The plan of the aqueduct. (Engineer reappears) Quickly, change some of the routes on this and see that a messenger delivers it to the Doctor.
It shall be done.
Now, not only shall they go down into the aqueduct with useless armaments, but they will be hopelessly lost as well.
